results.title: [Korean artist] (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Begins with a resume of ancient Korean art. Then introduces the work of Lee Hyung Pyo, a contemporary Korean painter. Lee’s continuing artistic problem is to find a way of bridging the distance between the traditional culture into which he was born and the inescapable influences of the present.
results.description: Begins with a resume of ancient Korean art. Then introduces the work of Lee Hyung Pyo, a contemporary Korean painter. holdings.name: 16mm film; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [Kill Bill] Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender, A Band Apart and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Volume two of The Bride’s (Uma Thurman) quest to exact revenge on those who prevented her from leaving the violent world of the hired killer. In “Kill Bill Vol. 1” The Bride is pregnant attending her wedding, when all are massacred and she is shot in the head leaving her in coma for four years. After recovering and killing the main perpetrators, she heads out in “Vol. 2” to find her mentor/ex-lover Bill (David Carradine) to kill him for ordering her assassination (and shooting her!). Fending off a few of his accomplices along the way, she battles these intense foes with the sword and anything else to hand. The Bride’s exceptional level of skill is not just hate-driven but substantiated in the teachings of a great master, Pai Mei (Gordon Liu). An homage to martial arts films from the East and West but still infused with the wit and humour of a Quentin Tarantino picture, “Kill Bill Vol. 2” is a classic revenge story with all of the requisite action sequences and fine storytelling. Cast includes Daryl Hannah, Michael Madsen, Michael Parks and Lucy Liu. WARNING: SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

holdings.name: DVD; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: [Kids' fun: a compilation of cartoon adventures]
results.creator_credit: Castle Films, Animafilm Studio and Romania Film
results.brief_description: A collection of Romanian and classic American animation. First up are four fun-filled Romanian cartoons designed for young children (Music and sound affects, no spoken words). The characters Michaela, Benny and Tommy are seen here having fun with all of their animal friends. Following is a collection of classic American cartoons made between the 1930’s and 1950’s including the first Heckle and Jeckle cartoon.
results.title_for_label: [Kids’ fun: a compilation of cartoon adventures]

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: The Big Dry
results.brief_description: The 1982-83 drought in North- west Victoria and South Australia impacted heavily on the environment. This tape examines the effect of the drought in the Mallee region in terms of soil conservation. This area experienced severe soil erosion as farmers were forced to overgraze livestock, in particular sheep.
results.description: The 1982-83 drought in North- west Victoria and South Australia impacted heavily on the environment. results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made using 16mm film.

This film shows some of the family travels through Europe in their Bedford camper van. We see the ferry crossing between Malmo, Sweden and Copenhagen, Denmark, a campground and a border check point.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 we see the ferry between Malmo, Sweden and Copenhagen, Denmark crossing the water; there is a large DFDS Seaways (a Danish shipping company) cruiser behind
00:00:24:00 a flock of seagulls flying over the deck of the boat
00:00:43:00 a campground, featuring colourful tents and the Malins’s camping set up
00:01:14:00 the Bedford van arrives at a checkpoint, pulling up beside a yellow Volkswagen Kombi van; there is a sign reading ‘Report here’ in multiple languages: Dutch, French, German and Swedish
00:01:37:00 the van drives onto a ferry with Union Jack flag painted onto the side
00:01:45:00 city streets in what appears to be London

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film takes place during a trip to Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea. The film shows members of the Royal Papua Yacht Club sailing on the harbour, from the perspective of another yacht.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 view of building painted with sign ‘Royal Papua Yacht Club’
00:00:11:00 yachts sailing on the water, including close ups of rigging and sails and what appears to be a bamboo mast
00:00:39:00 group of men on a yellow sailing yacht, filmed from yacht alongside
00:00:52:00 yachts sailing on the harbour from different vantage points: in some shots open sea can be seen in the background; in others the cliffs of the harbour and the buildings of the city of Port Moresby
00:01:35:00 we see a man seated on the deck of the boat, smiling at the camera while adjusting ropes in the wind
00:02:16:00 a second man in a short sleeve shirt releasing a large floating buoy onto the water over the side of the boat; the buoy is decorated with the classic shield logo of BP (formerly British Petroleum), with yellow initials on a green shield design
00:02:32:00 the man is now seated on the edge of the boat while a third man cleans a firearm

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film features vintage cars departing on a Veteran Car Rally that took place between London and Brighton, with models including Clément-Bayard, Fiat and Métallurgique cars from the 1900s and 1910s.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 two men working on a Clément-Bayard car with burgundy leather interior
00:00:16:00 two men driving a cream-coloured Fiat car
00:00:52:00 close up of the front of a red and black Métallurgique model
00:01:26:00 the departure of a green 1912 Rover
00:01:52:00 two men in an open red 1905 Itala, with cover over their legs
00:03:35:00 a man and woman in a red 1916 Ford T

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a collection of scenes including a QANTAS plane leaving the airport, a group of family and friends in the backyard of a suburban home, dressed for a celebration, and the Malinses’s Bedford camper van.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a group of kangaroos in grassy parkland
00:00:12:00 close-up of kangaroo with joey in her pouch
00:00:48:00 QANTAS airplane on the tarmac of Melbourne Airport, departing
00:01:21:00 a group of people on the lawn in a garden dressed in 1970s style clothing at what seems to be a celebration - great examples of 70s patterns and dress styles
00:01:55:00 close-up of man in white pants and pink check shirt with a pink ribbon flower attached to his back pocket digging in the garden bed; purple hydrangeas at the back of the bed and wishbone ferns at the front
00:02:10:00 exterior of a suburban brick house with venetian blinds and pot plants
00:02:19:00 a man drives a two-toned green Morris van out of the driveway
00:02:35:00 George and Sybil Malins with their Bedford camper van in a campground

00:00:48:00 QANTAS airplane on the tarmac of Melbourne Airport, departing
00:01:21:00 a group of people on the lawn in a garden dressed in 1970s style clothing at what seems to be a celebration - great examples of 70s patterns and dress styles
00:01:55:00 close-up of man in white pants and pink check shirt with a pink ribbon flower attached to his back pocket digging in the garden bed; purple hydrangeas at the back of the bed and wishbone ferns at the front
00:02:10:00 exterior of a suburban brick house with venetian blinds and pot plants
00:02:19:00 a man drives a two-toned green Morris van out of the driveway
00:02:35:00 George and Sybil Malins with their Bedford camper van in a campground
description_for_label:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a collection of scenes including a QANTAS plane leaving the airport, a group of family and friends in the backyard of a suburban home, dressed for a celebration, and the Malinses’s Bedford camper van.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a group of kangaroos in grassy parkland
00:00:12:00 close-up of kangaroo with joey in her pouch
00:00:48:00 QANTAS airplane on the tarmac of Melbourne Airport, departing
00:01:21:00 a group of people on the lawn in a garden dressed in 1970s style clothing at what seems to be a celebration - great examples of 70s patterns and dress styles

results.title: [The Royal Tour of Australia]
results.brief_description:
This film is a documentary of the visit of Queen Elizabeth II to Australia in 1954. A highlight is an event at the MCG in Melbourne in which 17,000 children participated. At one point, the excited children break rank and surround the royals jeep to get a closer view so that Prince Philip starts to shoo them out of the way of the vehicle.

Another Prince Philip moment is at the Davis Cup tennis tournament in Melbourne where he is seen speaking at length to the coach and the players who assume they should pass by quickly.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘The Royal Tour of Australia’ and ‘The Queen visits Hobart’
00:00:14:00 view of a ship on the water followed by the Queen and Prince Phillip looking through binoculars from the ship’s deck
00:00:30:00 waving to the crowd, sailing into harbour and looking out over the waving crowds and military assembly
00:01:04:00 the Queen and Prince Philip stand in the back of a military jeep, waving to huge cheering crowd as they pass by
00:01:10:00 title ‘The Queen in Melbourne’
00:01:17:00 the Queen descending the steps at Parliament House, Melbourne accompanied by be-wigged members of the judiciary and other officials
00:01:40:00 greeting the crowds at the MCG (Melbourne Cricket Ground) including veterans in wheelchairs
00:02:11:00 an young girl and boy present flowers to the Queen and Prince Philip
00:02:18:00 the Queen and Prince Philip keenly watching horse racing at Flemington Racecourse in Melbourne
00:03:29:00 at the Davis Cup match in Melbourne, the Queen presents a trophy to coach Harry Hopman, and players Ken Rosewall and Lou Hoad
00:04:04:00 a visit to Melbourne war memorial, the Shrine of Remembrance where the Queen delivers a dedication speech, after which the Queen presses a button which lights the eternal flame in the forecourt
00:05:35:00 military aircraft fly overhead in the shape of a capital E as Prince Philip attends the Flinders Naval base in Victoria, and watches a parade of naval personnel, including women (an unusual element according to the narration)
00:06:19:00 the royals watch a parade at Point Cook airforce base
00:06:40:00 the Queen and Prince Philip are shown the operations of the open cut coal mine at Yallourn in Victoria by the Chairman of the State Board for Electricity, Mr Hunt
00:07:18:00 children participate in an exhibition of maypole dancing at the MCG for the Queen and Prince Philip
00:08:05:00 the Queen and Prince Philip in an open jeep, with Prince Philip ‘directing traffic’ as children surround the vehicle
00:08:14:00 title ‘The end’

Note - 08/09/2022 Ann Jones (née Vernon) wrote to ACMI to say she was 10 years old and was from West Coburg Primary School. When the word ‘Welcome’ was formed she was at the top corner of the ‘C’. I remember Her Majesty driving past us and waving.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

A short film of a road trip to Albany, Western Australia, including a visit to the whale processing station, in operation at the time of the film. The Cheynes Beach Whaling Station, located at Frenchman Bay in King George Sound, east of Albany, operated from 1952 to 1978 and was the last operating whaling station in Australia.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 kangaroo in open bushland with gumtrees in the background, filmed at dusk or dawn
00:00:18:00 men working on the whale processing station, cutting large pieces of a whale carcass and hosing down the deck
00:01:06:00 a signpost pointing to ‘Albany (21)’ in one direction and ‘Whaling Station (1)’ in the other, with the coastline in the background
00:01:15:00 view from inside the front windscreen of a vehicle driving along the road, leaving Western Australia; a sign gradually appears reading ‘State Border, Come Again to Western Australia’
00:01:36:00 what appears to be a 1950s model Bedford camper van driving down the road through swirls of dust
